**Running Crontab in docker with environment variables**

This document explains how you can run a crontab inside docker container with environment variables such that you can have different setting like database hostname with minimum manual configurations.

sample code:

[https://bitbucket.org/hkibg/sample/src/master/docker-compose-env-crontab/](https://bitbucket.org/hkibg/sample/src/master/docker-compose-env-crontab/)

**Prerequisites of this tutorial**

Basic knowledge of:

- --Docker
- --Docker-compose
- --Crontab

**File structures in this tutorial**

#Dockerfile of demo image

Dockerfile.dc-env-crontab

#crontab file and entrypoint script file

_src_

- crontab

- entrypoint.sh

#Docker compose definition file, environment variable files

_composer_

- docker-compose.yml

- dev.env

- prod.env



**Step by step explanations**

1. Create the Dockerfile of demo image, I use an ubuntu base image in this demo

The Dockerfile: [Dockerfile.dc-env-crontab]

 ![](data:image/*;base64,)

Note the permission setting of crontab and entrypoint.sh

Write the content of the crontab file [src/crontab]

 ![](data:image/*;base64,)

The crontab will run every minute and echo &quot;Hello $NAME&quot; to the temp file /tmp/crontab

A few things to note:

- --The crontab file here must specific the user, i.e. **root** in this example. If you use crontab -e and add the line manually, you do not have to specify the user
- --There must be a blank line at the end of the crontab file

Setup the entrypoint file [src/entrypoint.sh]

 ![](data:image/*;base64,)

Explanation:

When you are running scripts with crontab and environment variables inside a docker container, do include Line 2 which prints all the environment variables in a file such that they can be read by the cronjob

Line 4 starts the cron daemon

**Build the docker image:**

Now create the image with the following command:

sudo docker build -f Dockerfile.dc-env-crontab -t cpluk3/dc-env-crontab-demo .

Replace cpluk3 (my user name in docker hub) with your own user name



**Docker Compose**

Docker composer is a tool for defining and running multiple docker containers. It is not a must in this article but makes life easier.

 ![](data:image/*;base64,)

We start two containers, one for the development environment (dc-env-crontab-dev) and another one (dc-env-crontab-prod) for production environment. Both containers created from the same image.

Meanings of the parameters:

image: specify the name of the docker image to run

container\_name: name of the container

network\_mode: assign network (bridge) mode for this container.

env\_file: specify the name of the environment file (dev.env for development container and prod.env for the production container)



The environment files

 ![](data:image/*;base64,)

The two environments have different value for the same environment variable NAME defined.

Run the composer file:

The -f flag specifies the desired composer file and the -d flag set the container to run in daemon mode (background)

sudo docker-compose -f composer/docker-compose.yml up -d

**Results:**

Login to the containers and verify the results after 1 minute:

 ![](data:image/*;base64,)

The temp files show the crontab and environment variable are set correctly.
